reviewText:
There are very few games on my large steam game library that I truly regret buying.  This is one of them.

I will admit it is mostly personal preference, but I found the glitchy jumping around off of platforms and getting killed incredibly unenjoyable, with experienced players eviscerating me again and again.  I played for an hour or so and never came back in the 5 or so years since I bought it.

Enjoyable if you like a simple multiplayer Joust-y experience I suppose, but I did not enjoy it.
voteText: 22 of 36 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR
Flying Robot Ninjas. LAN only. So much fun with friends!

A fast review:
Wicked little game, awesome for LAN parties, it only takes about 15 mins to get the hang of it, an hour to really master it, and then it's all Unreal Tournament Deathmatch Arena, with 1hit kills and autolocking. IS SO MUCH FUN.

Pity the servers are down, and the multiplayer is dead... but LAN is still a thing. I used to run mini tournaments in my internet cafe with this game all the time! everyone loved it! (except the LOL players for some reason)

Ignore the haters of this game, they likely didn't evn understand it for what it is. See above.
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Plain Sight's concept is very cool. Combining the gravity platforming from Mario Galaxy with fast pace multiplayer arena combat. Only how the combat works isn't that well executed. You need to auto lock on enemies and use a dash attack to kill them. The frags only count to your score when you self detonate. Combat like Rune or UT99 Instagib would have been better in my opinion.\n\nBut the biggest problem Plain Sight has is that the multiplayer is dead. That's almost always the problem with small indie titles that focuses on multiplayer. You can play against bots. But I would say that it's only really worth it if you got a couple of friends to play it with.

reviewText:
Suicidal robots, although with no players.

Multiplayer third-person deathmatch involving suicidal robots and gravity.

I really like its graphics style, the way it plays and how you can upgrade your robot using the experience points. Sadly though, the multiplayer community is dead, so unless you have someone to play it with, you're stuck with the offline mode which doesn't provide as much enjoyment as you could get out of this game.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This was the first game I ever got on Steam. IN FACT...it was the game that my friend told me he was gifting to me, which meant I had to install Steam. Ah, I'm so glad I did. :D #nostalgia #thankyouLordDust

AS for the game, it's a third-person suicidal robot simulator. You go around slicing up other robots with your sword and then when you want your kills to COUNT, you have to self-distruct yourself.

Sounds simple, right? Well, it would be if it weren't for the fact you can run on walls, ceilings, etc. Basically any surface on the map you automagically cling to it. The 'bound/unbound' mechanic takes a little bit to get used to, but it's a unique game & one I recommend at least TRYING once in your life.

*edit [12/21/15]: I just heard multiplayer servers are down. :( I don't know much else, but if MP comes back in any way, I'll update*

The servers are back up! Hamachi did not work for me and my friends.

+Graphics are great

reviewText:
OMG, after years the master-server is back up !!!

This was, when i remember correctly, the first game i bought (as a 4-pack) on steam after being forced to install and use steam because of Half Life 2. And it was a blast.

It takes a while to get behind this silly looking little thing and to understand the (3 times changes) mechanics. It looks sooooo simple but theres a lot more to it then just running around and hitting each other with a sword before comitting suicide in an esplosion to get the points. Its really fast, you need to get the timings right, know your movements to get rid of lock-ons, know how to repel, use the perks wisely ... Its really easy to just play but hard to master.

It had one of the most friendly comunity i´ve ever met in an online game with almonst no toxic players like we used to have today. A lot of the guys in my friendlist i´ve met through this game.

But ... it died after one and a half year. Then the master server died so nobody could login anyway ...
So now the masterserver is back, but no servers to find wich is really really sad for such a fun and exceptionally good designed take on a multiplayer title.

To the devs, if they read this. You have added joypad-support which is good for a third-person-title like this. You should consider adding a 4-player-splitscreen to this. It would really help to keep the game alive.
Everybody loves to get some friends on a couch, grab some beer and shout at each other while playing games. And this would fit perfekt. I´ve read something bout plainsight 2 which is great to hear, but don´t let this little gem die again.
And by the way the leaderboards died even earlier then the game itself ;) (not counting anymore)

So, now i have to activate some buddies to play this (after hosting a server ^^). In fact this is the only game that has me more addicted then rocket-league, which means A LOT!!

tldr: get it, lose a lot of matches while learning, love it, have fun

sorry for my bad english - but i think everybody gets the point

reviewText: this is the worst purchase i have ever made, and considering it only costs 4.99 that says allot. the game advertises itself as a fun little hack and slash where you can advance in power and explode in cool environments, hell for 4.99 that sounds good to me. what it should be advertised as however is a game where you play as an angry blurry spec as it desperately tries to fight the tyrany of horrible buggy gravity physics while homing instant kill attacks are being lobbed at you by those 19 other players the game so gratiously provides. i only ever found about 5 people playing this game at a time though, perhaps because having a fastpaced game with weird buggy gravity where you move by sonic the hedgehog style homing attack obscures the action to the point that there is even less skill involved than there normally is. i ragequit this game in 3 hours.\nthis game gets my -1/10

reviewText:
This game is AMAZING!

I know it sounds over enthusiastic, but seriously, it's frigging awesome.

You're playing as suicidal Ninja Robots that's fighting in space over getting the most energy.
The way you go about getting energy is by killing other people, and then blowing yourself up. When you blow yourself up, you gain however many points you've accumulated so far.

Does it sound awesome? Thought so..

Aside from the TDM, DM, Conquest and CTF gamemodes there's also stuff like: Botzilla. Where it's 1 botzilla vs everyone else. Botzilla is this huge robot with a flaming sword, no charge up time and has a lot of HP.

The only thing that's a little sad about this game is the fact that not enough people play it=/

reviewText:
This is a very fun little game.  Single player, the bots become a little too easy to mash, but the levels are fascinating, the mechanics of the game are innovative and different.   The graphics are very simple, and ensure that you're not having that modern-game problem where you didn't see an enemy coming because of the foliage or mental textures.

The only thing I'm not overly keen on is the shallowness to the play.  There doesn't appear to be any tactics, or good spots to learn, etc.. Wherever you are, and whatever you're doing, it all comes down to: Who can spin around and attack first.  Because you spend so much time in freefall, and that the enemies have auto-lockon, it sometimes feels that it's just a click-fest.

That aside, it's whiled away many fun hours, and I've enjoyed all the levels (I think)...   If you want to have a LAN party, and need something light to fill a while between heavier FPS sessions, this is a very fun little game.

reviewText:
The gameplay is amusing but not perfect. The nature of the game makes it generally come to guessing if somebody is attacking you rather than actually seeing and reacting. (By the time you see them moving it's already too late to defend.)

The community is also lacking, or was last time I checked. There was a free weekend since then, so it may have been boosted, or maybe not. In my experience it was impossible to get a game past 3 or 4 people, and the only mode you'll find anybody in is straight deathmatch.

Probably fun to play with friends if you tell everybody to get online when you want to play, but dont expect to just hop into matches.

reviewText: If you are ever looking for a bit of rapid-fire action with a very dynamic game-field, Plain Sight can provide. You kill a lot, you die even more. But it's okay. In fact it's perfect. Controls are simple and intuitive, and gameplay concepts are fairly easy to understand. The learning curve can be a bit steep (the bare-bones tutorial doesn't give much away) but figuring out good tactics is half the fun.\n\nHowever, the game requires a solid internet connection, because multiplayer is the only way to go, and lag can ruin you effortlessly. As well, the multiplayer community isn't perpetually online, so whether or not you can set up the exhilariting large matches is hit-and-miss.

reviewText: Steam tells me that I have played this game for 84 minutes. That sounds about right because after about eighty minutes of jumping around and disemboweling myself over and over again I begin to feel like I'm watching that episode of Star Trek The Next Generation wherein the Enterprise was caught in a time loop forever doomed to explode and come back to life. Eventually they figured it out because they felt afterimages (or rather beforeimages) of their past (or rather future) selves. Plain Sight doesn't give you the luxury of premonitions, however its repetitive boringness is self evident in a way that infinite resetting time loops in space can never be. So I guess I should count myself lucky that I was trapped only for 84 minutes instead of thousands of years like Bill Murray. (Picard could kick Murray's ♥♥♥ any day of the week. Just FYI.)
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I don't see why there are as little people playing as there are. The game is fabulously quick paced, and requires some degree of skill. It is very nice eye-candy wise as well. There is no complex story or jaw dropping pre-scripted sequences, but you don't need those. Plain Sight is fun, exciting, and very original. Kudos to Beatnik for making a great game that has suicidal ninja robots fighting ninja robot dinosaurs.

reviewText:
A pretty fun simple game that requires an extremely heavy duty graphics card to implement the shaders. Do not bother if you only have a pretty good machine and graphics card. There are no settings for turning down graphics.

Purely an online game.

By collecting stars you can purchase lasting upgrades. Collecting 50 stars takes a hell-a-long time. There are around 9-16 boosters/upgrades ranging from 50-500stars. You can select 1-3 upgrades b4 a match.

I bought the 4 pack. My son was complaining a player was kicking his butt, I watched and he was cheating hardcore. The player was using every upgrade, when the upgrades were not allowed on this match. (some sort of fight the godzilla mode, & then you get to be it.) The other player was able to kill my sons godzilla in one hit, when it should have taken 1000.

Other than that one cheater, and having to give up my machine so my kids could log on to their accounts (their machines are only pretty good), this game is a whole lot of fun.

reviewText:
I must say: hands down this is the best game. It should've won game of the year, every year. This game is pure genius... the creators must've studied at harvard and MIT to develope such a godly, breathtaking game such as this... I am at loss for words to describe the pure ecstasy and bliss I feel while I attempt to play this god-like game with mere human hands...

I not only recommend for you to buy this game for yourself, but, please I am asking this of you, share the amazing intensity with everyone. Buy everyone you know this game and duel it out in an inivative and creative, original multiplayer gaming experience never before revealed.

Graphics: 10/10
Audio: 10/10
Multiplayer: 10/10
Replay value: 10/10
Visuals: 10/10

Over all this game is a perfect 10.
♥♥♥♥ your halo and keep your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ counter strike ♥♥♥♥ squad, I'm more than fine with this perfect game. This is the only game I will ever need.

Come at me bro, I'm in Plain Sight.

reviewText: SPACE NINJAS! Robot Ninjas. ROBOT NINJAS IN SPACE!\nChallenge your friends and their reflexes. Utilize torn up terrains and odd gravity wells, soar through space and outsmart opponents, ready to slice them open with a one-hit-crit in this high stakes combat game. But it's not just about landing kills. It's about building up a killstreak greater than your last in order to obtain more points and more power in the end. Great for LAN parties and fanatics of ninja clicks and killstreak boasting. Technically you could call this a third person melee game.
